marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Planter, owner of "Mount Airwell" mansion in Natchez (Adams Co.), Miss.
Deeds for slaves purchased by James Bisland, including one deed from Peter Bisland and another from William Bisland.
Bissell and Barker account of Mecklenburg Gold Mining Company,

Charlotte gold mining account. The heading of the two-page account (1832 Sept.) reads "Messrs. Bissell & Barker of Charlotte in acct. with the Mecklenburg gold mining company." Includes company's itemized listing of debits and credits.
Personal letters concerning W. A. Blair's changes of fortune as he moved from Portsmouth, Virginia, to Peoria and thence to St. Louis, Missouri.
A personal letter from Elizabeth Blackwell's daughter, Betsy, and her son-in-law, J. H. (Edmunds?); and a letter concerning interest on a loan.
Letters from cotton factors of Augusta, Georgia, describing the cotton market, prices, and futures.

Letters from Blackwell, a Methodist minister, to his brother Edmund B. Blackwell. Letters contain advice about moving from South Carolina to Mississippi or Alabama. Among topics are produce prices; crop conditions; commercial advantages; and land speculation. Blackwell wrote about sickness in his community, mentioning hemorrage of the lungs, bronchitis, bloody flux, congestive chills, typhoid, and cholera. Blackwell owned slaves, and commented on their health as well. Occasional religious exhortations are included, as well as comments on revivals, conferences, and conversions. In letter dated 1852 Dec. 29, the author described a hurricane in the Mississippi delta and referred to Judge Longstreet and the University of Mississippi.
Confederate soldier, from Macon (Bibb County), Ga.

Chiefly war letters from Blackshear, who was engaged to and eventually married Marian Baber, daughter of Ambrose Baber; and of George D. Smith, Confederate soldier and cousin of the Babers. The letters include descriptions of the fall of Port Royal, S.C., in 1861, and graphic descriptions of army life and activities on St. Simon's Island, Ga. Other correspondents wrote of the efforts of "Yankees" in 1865 to get teachers for African-American schools in Savannah, and impressions of Texas.
Miscellaneous material concerning a law firm.
Letters of N.L. Blakemore, connected with the Shenandoah Iron Works, concerning business conditions and prices.
Personal correspondence of David K. Blackwood with his brothers, J., James J., and M. J. Blackwood.

Correspondence of Cynthia and Mildred Blair, two young girls, with relatives and friends in Randolph County, N.C., and surrounding area. Contains references to social life and religion in the ante-bellum period. A few letters during the spring of 1861 show the anticipation of the outbreak of Civil War hostilities.
Letters, largely from Titus Bissell to his mother, discussing family affairs; two items describe the siege of Charleston during the Civil War and the part played by Titus's sons Tite and Neddy.

Chiefly family correspondence, but mentioning the progress of the Civil War and an organization known as the "Heroes of America," July 17, 1864, and material from 1877-1878 on the sale of manufactured tobacco in South Carolina.

Letters to Harriet from her brothers and cousins in the Confederate Army. There are references to the "Beef Club," evidently a co-operative food venture among the soldiers, and to the canal built for the siege of Vicksburg.

Letters from J. A. Dunn, overseer of Blackmon's plantation near Point Jefferson, Louisiana, about the building of a cotton gin, illness among the slaves, Civil War refugee life at Walnut Hill, Arkansas, and the behavior of slaves under French occupation.
Confederate soldier, from Person County, N.C.
Letters of a private in the 35th North Carolina Regiment describing camp life near Richmond, Va., and in Martin County, N.C.
Charlotte (Mecklenburg Co.), N.C. resident with Union loyalties.

Collection consists of three letters from Bissell to his uncle. One concerns his feelings on the South, "Radical" victories, and Johnson's course. The others affirm his Union loyalties, criticizing rebels' retention of power and property and Southern resentment toward Reconstruction. He believed these feelings caused friction in the family, turned others against him and could ultimately have lead to a worse form of slavery for African Americans.
Partially processed collection. Cataloged from accession records.
